objdescid.compdate: c. 1779-80?The date, based on stylistic considerations, is far from certain.

objinfo.medium: pencilThe pencil inscription, lower right, appears to be signed "LJR" (Lessing J. Rosenwald), who probably wrote this inscription after he acquired the work c. 1938. This inscription reads "I doubt that these [a reference to both sides of the leaf] are Blake."
objinfo.support: laid paperBlake added a strip of laid paper, about 5.2 cm. wide, along the left side of the leaf (bottom of the leaf for the recto drawing).
objinfo.pennednumbers: noneThe pencil inscription, lower right, appears to be signed "LJR" (Lessing J. Rosenwald), who probably wrote this inscription after he acquired the work c. 1938. This inscription reads "I doubt that these [a reference to both sides of the leaf] are Blake."

provenance.name: National Gallery of Art, Washington, D. C.
provenance.note: Early history unknown; Alexander Macmillan by 1876; William A. White by 1905; "sold at an unidentified sale 22 December 1938" (Butlin 115) at which bought by the dealer A. S. W. Rosenbach; acquired, probably c. 1938, by Lessing J. Rosenwald; given by Rosenwald in 1943 to the National Gallery of Art, Washington, D. C.

repository.addressline: Constitution Avenue NW, between 3rd and 9th Streets
Mailing Address: 2000B South Club Drive, Landover, Maryland 20785

desc.objtitle:
Copy of the Belvedere Torso,
object 1 (Butlin 115 verso)

objnote.p: The pencil inscription, lower right, appears to be signed "LJR" (Lessing J. Rosenwald), who probably wrote this inscription after he acquired the work c. 1938. This inscription reads "I doubt that these [a reference to both sides of the leaf] are Blake." Blake's authorship of these drawings is now generally accepted by Blake authorities, including Butlin. For the monochrome wash drawing on the recto of this leaf, see Moses Staying the Plague.

illustration.illusobjdesc: In the top half of the drawing, a muscular torso bent to the right is seen from the back. A partial sketch of a right foot on a sculptural base occupies the lower half. The upper sketch is likely a copy of the Belvedere torso, which Blake may have drawn from a cast.

component.illusobjdesc: In the top half of the design, a muscular torso, presumably male, bent to the right is seen from the back. It is likely a copy of the Belvedere torso, which Blake may have drawn from a cast.
A sketch of a right foot on a rounded sculptural base occupies the lower half of the design. Shown from the ankle downward, the foot faces forward.
